title: Huly Core Architecture
body_html:
Huly Core Architecture

Overview

Huly is built around a document-centric model with a transaction pipeline and a plugin-based server architecture. Understanding these concepts is key to integrating webhooks natively.

Core Concepts

Documents (Doc)

  • Everything is a document: issues, projects, comments, attachments
  • Each document has a class, space (workspace/space), and system fields (modifiedOn/by)

Transactions (Tx)

  • All changes are represented as transactions:
    • TxCreateDoc<T>: create a document
    • TxUpdateDoc<T>: update document operations
    • TxRemoveDoc<T>: delete document
  • Triggers react to batches of transactions (TxCUD<Doc>[])

Plugin Architecture

  • Server-side plugins add features without touching the core
  • Each plugin often has a -resources package for concrete implementations
  • Plugins provide triggers, functions, models, and API endpoints

Triggers

  • Trigger functions subscribe to document change events
  • Signature: (txes: TxCUD<Doc>[], control: TriggerControl) => Promise<Tx[]>
  • Can create new transactions (e.g., notifications, webhook events)

Model System

  • TypeScript decorators define schema (@Model, @Prop)
  • Strong typing across packages

Why This Matters for Webhooks

  • Webhooks should be generated by triggers that observe transactions
  • Filtering and payload creation can use the hierarchy and model metadata
  • Delivery & retry should be asynchronous and resilient
